definition:
Let $G$ be a Lie group or algebraic group. $G$ is called [*reductive*]{}
over a field $k$ if every representation of $G$ over $k$ is completely
reducible

For example, a finite group is reductive over a field $k$ if and only if
its order is not divisible by the characteristic of $k$ (by Maschke’s
theorem). A complex Lie group is reductive if and only if it is a direct
product of a semisimple group and an algebraic torus.
